Django-redis 4.11.0 (latest stable) is incompatible with msgpack 1.0.0 (latest stable)
items.body:
When using `django-redis` 4.11.0 with `msgpack` 1.0.0, the following exception happens:

```
TypeError: unpackb() got an unexpected keyword argument 'encoding'
```

This has been fixed in 7aad69ed11c84c4c1ea1f992b01b652ba173a2b1 but there has been no stable release that includes it.

It would be good to have a new stable release that includes this fix as `msgpack` 1.0.0 is now the latest published stable release.

items.title: Documentation site is not available
support for set and expire as one call
items.body: We recently had an issue in django where a key was set but its TTL was 0. The page_cache decorator has a timeout/expiry set to 5 mins (60*50) for all our views. Looks like an intermittent issue where most likely SET was called but something happened to the EXPIRE call. If this was done all in one call using SETEX this would prevent the expiry from being 0, and if the SETEX failed at least it would be set correctly next time the view was cached. Any thoughts or opinions if this is even feasible? Thanks much.

items.title: Missing support for thread_local param.
items.body:
As mentioned in a [pull request](https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/pull/393), this package is missing support for the `thread_local` keyword in the `lock` method of the `DefaultClient` and `ShardClient`.

Trivial fix, add `**options**` to both methods:

```
    def lock(self, key, version=None, timeout=None, sleep=0.1,
             blocking_timeout=None, client=None, **options):
        if client is None:
            client = self.get_client(write=True)

        key = self.make_key(key, version=version)
        return client.lock(key, timeout=timeout, sleep=sleep,
                           blocking_timeout=blocking_timeout, **options)
```

I'd recommend adding `**options**` over adding a new keyword because it will reduce overhead and has no downside, since `Redis.lock` will throw a `TypeError` if someone tries to submit invalid option.

items.title: set_many seems to make a network call per key
items.body:
Hello,

I was profiling some code that made heavy use of "set_many". In the source code, it is written that set_many is much faster than setting individual keys.

However, the call graph from cProfile -> KCacheGrind is the following:
https://i.imgur.com/DujxFVP.png

It seems like recv and the whole network stack is used for each key. That would also explain the fact that the function takes 48 ms although a RTT to Redis is ~0.1ms

Maybe am I wrong, I'd really appreciate you correct me so I can understand.

Thank you,

items.title: Default client does not handle string value for timeout
items.body:
I was hunting down the cause of a `ResponseError` with django_redis and after a lot of searching I found that my timeout value was being passed in as a string (my fault).

I traced the issue down to [this line](https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/blob/302359554427c7b7f36380aa9f0ce20dea906879/django_redis/client/default.py#L130). If the timeout value received is a string like `'3'` then the timeout is set to one-thousand threes instead of 3000. e.g. `333333333333333333333333333333...`

The traceback looks like this:
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/engstrom/code/django-redis/django_redis/cache.py", line 32, in _decorator
    return method(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/engstrom/code/django-redis/django_redis/cache.py", line 67, in set
    return self.client.set(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/engstrom/code/django-redis/django_redis/client/default.py", line 150, in set
    raise ConnectionInterrupted(connection=client, parent=e)
django_redis.exceptions.ConnectionInterrupted: Redis ResponseError: value is not an integer or out of range
```

The message is pretty obvious now that I know the cause but it took me longer than I'd like to admit to realize that initially. Anyway, I thought it might be worth handling this case to save someone else time in the future.

items.title: django-redis is incompatible with redis-py >= 3
items.body:
From the redis-py release notes:

> Only bytes, strings and numbers (ints, longs and floats) are acceptable for keys and values.

See https://github.com/andymccurdy/redis-py/blob/9b03af26dc829beea232a3248768de933f4c3b67/CHANGES#L9-L15

The `CacheKey` class used by django-redis is no longer supported.

I'm happy to open a PR, but I wanted to ask first if it's better to drop `CacheKey` or to cast keys to strings right before sending them to redis-py?  The latter would be more work, but retain the intended use of `CacheKey`:

> A stub string class that we can use to check if a key was created already.

items.title: add() returns None instead of False
items.body:
The API for add() is supposed to return False if the key exists, but instead returns None.
I've made a quick fix + PR but you guys might want to add additional checks.

items.title: Error when locking while using mockredis
items.body:
I've setup `mockredis.mock_redis_client` as my `REDIS_CLIENT_CLASS` but when I use `lock()` I get the following exception:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/Oskar/git/proj/app.py", line 155, in run
    with cache.lock(lock_key, timeout=60):
  File "/Users/Oskar/.pyenv/versions/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django_redis/cache.py", line 32, in _decorator
    return method(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/Oskar/.pyenv/versions/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django_redis/cache.py", line 148, in lock
    return self.client.lock(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/Oskar/.pyenv/versions/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django_redis/client/default.py", line 237, in lock
    blocking_timeout=blocking_timeout)
TypeError: lock() got an unexpected keyword argument 'blocking_timeout'
```

Looking at the [source for mockredis](https://github.com/locationlabs/mockredis/blob/fd4e3117066ff0c24e86ebca007853a8092e3254/mockredis/client.py#L77) we can see that it doesn't accept the `blocking_timeout` in the `lock` method but instead in the `__init__` method of the class

items.title: Django Cache Prefix / Version
items.body:
Django allows you to remove the default cache prefix / version and provide your own cache key function. This library is not fully compatible with that functionality.

We should make these changes... happy to make a PR if you'll give me permission:

from `django_redis/utils.py`
```
def original_key(self):
    key = self._key.rsplit(":", 1)[-1]
    return key

def default_reverse_key(key):
    return key.split(':', 2)[-1]
```

items.title: get_redis_connection() should support decode_responses kwarg
items.body: Do you think this is a good idea? :)

items.title: `touch` method is unimplemented
items.body:
Attempting to use the `touch` method introduced in Django 2.1 (as documented [here](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.1/topics/cache/#basic-usage)) results in the base class raising a NotImplementedError:

`raise NotImplementedError('subclasses of BaseCache must provide a touch() method')`

items.title: Sentinel support in django-redis
items.body:
Currently there is no support for sentinel in django-redis. There are several implementation e.g. [1] but they are not working with current version of django-redis. django-redis has multiple closed issues for sentinel support: #186, #87, Is it feasible to add new sentinel client to django-redis itself? Default client is already supporting Master-Slave configuration, hence adding sentinel support should not be big development effort. I am willing to fix [1] and create PR to django-redis. Is welkome such contribution to django-redis?

[1] https://github.com/SpatialBuzz/django-redis-sentinel

Thanks

items.title: Setting the timeout using a named argument does not work

Setting a cache key like this `cache.set('foo', 'bar', timeout=10) ` does not work, if the timeout argument is skipped it works, `cache.set('foo', 'bar', 10)`.

Can't say it is a very important issue but I thought I should let you know.
The documentation example is using the `timeout` argument.
http://niwinz.github.io/django-redis/latest/#_infinite_timeout

items.title: Latest version no longer compatible with mockredis?
items.body:
Hello,
As Fakeredis seems to be out, I switched to the suggested mockredis, which seems to also be having issue, in the latest pypi version I'm getting this error:
```
    @property
    def client(self):
        """
            Lazy client connection property.
            """
        if self._client is None:
>           self._client = self._client_cls(self._server, self._params, self)
E           TypeError: mock_redis_client() takes 0 positional arguments but 3 were given

.tox/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django_redis/cache.py:62: TypeError
```
IDK exactly how recent this is and maybe this is known or maybe I'm missing something or maybe the better option is to just switch to using either local memory or dummy for testing... thoughts on this appreciated.

As a side note I'd also like to point out that the documentation probably needs updating: 
http://niwinz.github.io/django-redis/latest/#_pluggable_redis_client
Looks like `"REDIS_CLIENT_CLASS"` has been changed to just `"CLIENT_CLASS"`

Cheers!

items.title: django-redis==3.8.4 fails with django 1.11

django-redis==3.8.4 is using `get_cache` [1] which was removed in django 1.9 [2]

```

```

[1] https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/blob/3.8.x/django_redis/__init__.py#L3
[2] https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/releases/1.9/#features-removed-in-1-9

items.title: Incompatible with Django Cache API for default values on client.get
items.body:
Hi, I'm running into some issues when using `django-redis` with some third party packages that make use of Django cache's [default get support](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/cache/#basic-usage):

>cache.get() can take a default argument. This specifies which value to return if the object doesn’t exist in the cache:

```
>>> cache.get('my_key', 'has expired')
'has expired'
```

When using this with `django-redis`, I'm getting this exception:

```
File ".../.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_redis/cache.py", line 33, in _decorator
    return method(self, *args, **kwargs)
File ".../.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_redis/cache.py", line 82, in get
    client=client)
TypeError: get() got an unexpected keyword argument 'default'
```

It looks like this is because the `get` API that `django-redis` exposes doesn't support the second default arg:

https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/blob/master/django_redis/cache.py#L81

Any thoughts? Happy to help with a PR.

Thanks!

items.title: Should clear issue FLUSHDB?
items.body:
Currently [.clear()](https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/blob/202e4c319d28128b7bd4197477a503421e48faa8/django_redis/client/default.py#L291) iterates over keys using `scan_iter` and then for each calls `delete` on the key.

For large caches this can generate many calls to redis when I believe a `FLUSHDB` would be a better option.

Is there a reason why the `scan_iter`/`delete` approach was taken or would a PR that implemented a `FLUSHDB` be welcomed?

This shim works:
```
from fakeredis import FakeStrictRedis

class StupidRedis(FakeStrictRedis):
    def get_client(self, *args, **kwargs):

```

items.title: cache.clear() ignores KEY_PREFIX
items.body:
The current implementation of clear is:

```python
    def clear(self, client=None):
        """
        Flush all cache keys.
        """

        if client is None:
            client = self.get_client(write=True)

        try:
            count = 0
            for key in client.scan_iter("*"):
                client.delete(key)
                count += 1
            return count
        except _main_exceptions as e:
            raise ConnectionInterrupted(connection=client, parent=e)
```

`client.scan_iter("*")` iterates over all keys regardless KEY_PREFIX. As a result, the whole redis database is cleared and not only the keys starting the configured KEY_PREFIX.

This was fixed before (https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/issues/168) but has been broken again in https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/commit/a71d9fbc3a455fcd739e59b884c4c7e99bc21ff5 when fixing https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/issues/223.

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [django-redis](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/django-redis), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install django-redis with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: Low performance of delete_pattern
items.body:
When the `delete_pattern` is being called with a pattern that will match a large number of keys then `scan_iter` is being called number of times using `SCAN`. 
The default `count` value for `SCAN` is 10 which is the number of keys being returned per call. This results in poor performance when using `delete_pattern`. `SCAN` is being called numerous times which adds lots of overhead.

items.title: Question regarding incr() implementation
items.body:
At first I assumed the incr() method would behave as the corresponding redis command (INCR or INCRBY) but it turns out an error is raised if the key does not exists. I've reviewed the code and similar issues and this seems to be deliberate; some problems in the past regarding the atomicity of the operation.

So what I'm wondering is, if the redis command is atomic in itself, why the lua script? Why not use the method contained in the "core" redis library : https://github.com/andymccurdy/redis-py/blob/d49aaacb7dd454781fd9cb2cd2cb92e9c07d7d31/redis/client.py#L999

In my current use case I can simply get the connection to the redis client underneath and use the function I've just linked. But I had to ask the question as I'm assuming there is some reason I do not understand somewhere in there.

items.title: Since 4.4.0, .clear() does not completely clear its cache
items.body:
### Versions

Django: 1.10 (but I don't think the specific Django version is a factor)
django-redis: 4.4.0 and higher.

### Steps to reproduce

Run this:

```
import os

from django.conf import settings
settings.configure()

from django.core.cache.backends.filebased import FileBasedCache
from django_redis.cache import RedisCache

def dump(label, cache, key, version):
    print label, "key:", key, "version:", version, "result:", \
        cache.get(key, version=version)

def test_cache(label, cache):
    cache.set("foo", 1)
    cache.set("foo", 2, version=2)
    dump(label + " before clear", cache, "foo", 1)
    dump(label + " before clear", cache, "foo", 2)
    cache.clear()
    dump(label + " after clear", cache, "foo", 1)
    dump(label + " after clear", cache, "foo", 2)

# You must be able to create files at this location.
fb_cache = FileBasedCache("/tmp/fb", {})
test_cache("fb_cache", fb_cache)

# Change this if localhost:6379 is not okay.
redis_cache = RedisCache("localhost:6379", {})
test_cache("redis_cache", redis_cache)
```

### Expected Results

After the call to `cache.clear()`, getting old keys should no longer return any results. So:

```
fb_cache before clear key: foo version: 1 result: 1
fb_cache before clear key: foo version: 2 result: 2
fb_cache after clear key: foo version: 1 result: None
fb_cache after clear key: foo version: 2 result: None
redis_cache before clear key: foo version: 1 result: 1
redis_cache before clear key: foo version: 2 result: 2
redis_cache after clear key: foo version: 1 result: None
redis_cache after clear key: foo version: 2 result: None
```

We see that both the file based cache and the redis cache return behave the same before and after `.clear()` is called.

These expected results can be obtained with any version of django-redis prior to 4.4.0.

### Actual Results

With 4.4.0 or higher:

```
fb_cache before clear key: foo version: 1 result: 1
fb_cache before clear key: foo version: 2 result: 2
fb_cache after clear key: foo version: 1 result: None
fb_cache after clear key: foo version: 2 result: None
redis_cache before clear key: foo version: 1 result: 1
redis_cache before clear key: foo version: 2 result: 2
redis_cache after clear key: foo version: 1 result: None
redis_cache after clear key: foo version: 2 result: 2
```

The last line of the output is where there is a problem. The key `foo` with version 2 was not cleared from the cache.

### Observations

This is not a theoretical problem, but one that actually happens in production. People using Django CMS and configuring it to have Django CMS' page cache use a cache that uses django-redis will run into problems because Django CMS makes substantial use of versioning. The net effect on Django CMS is that after the cache has been "cleared", some keys remain in the cache and eventually as the CMS increases the current version of the keys in the cache it will hit old keys and send stale data to clients. I was lucky that I've run into the problem while performing testing on one of my sites. Tests that used to pass stopped passing. When I inspected the HTML returned by Django, it looked test B was receiving data that would have been generated by test A. I did clear my caches correctly so I was at a loss as to where the problem was coming from. The tests started passing again after I reverted django-redis to 4.3.0.

I'm convinced the that problem lies wholly in django-redis. Django's [documentation for caches](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/topics/cache/#basic-usage) says:

> Be careful with this; clear() will remove everything from the cache, not just the keys set by your application.

It is not clear what the scope of the `.clear()` is but for as long as I can remember, I've know this to mean that Django won't care about the key prefix set with the cache. And indeed if you examine the code of any of cache backends bundled with Django, you'll find that none of them care about the key prefix when they clear the cache. The DB-based one, for instance, does a plain "DELETE FROM [[table]]". This nukes everything in the table. The file based cache will exclude a suffix that is added to all the files created for the cache but does not otherwise care about what key prefix is used by the cache. 

And yes, this means that if Django's settings declare two caches with different prefixes but pointing to the same location, then when I clear one cache I'm also clearing the other. This is how Django caches behave.

Looks to me like pull request #169 is where things went astray.

```
    for key in all_keys:
TypeError: 'CacheKey' object is not iterable
```

After some poking around, I think the reason is that `django-redis` uses `CacheKey` as a key (https://github.com/niwinz/django-redis/blob/master/django_redis/util.py#L33), while `fakeredis` has a lot of checks like `isinstance(keys, string_types)` (e.g.  https://github.com/jamesls/fakeredis/blob/master/fakeredis.py#L1454-L1463) `CacheKey` isn't a subclass of `str`, so `fakeredis` breaks.

items.title: Documentation update: middleware
items.body:
Thanks for a great plugin. I almost gave up on it entirely though because I couldn't get it working after following the directions. I put the CACHE dictionary in settings.py but nothing ever showed up in my Redis store.

The documentation does not mention that the Django caching middleware needs to be enabled. I figured this much out from [here](http://michal.karzynski.pl/blog/2013/07/14/using-redis-as-django-session-store-and-cache-backend/).

In settings.py, the middleware class list needs to reflect the following, in this order:

```
MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = [
    'django.middleware.cache.UpdateCacheMiddleware',
    (everything else),
    'django.middleware.cache.FetchFromCacheMiddleware',
]
```

For Django 1.9 I only had to add the last line, but my understanding is that both need to be added in older versions.

items.title: Use raw key to fetch data from redis.
items.body:
Hi, I was actually hoping is there any way to use raw key to fetch data from redis in django-redis. Django changes the key passed internally but Django also provides a way to override make_key function and pass 'KEY_FUNCTION' : make_key, in setting of caches to use raw key.

I did same in django-redis to fetch raw data which was populated in redis from some other process, so could not actually use django's customized way to change passed key and then fetch data.

my make key function is very plain 

```
def make_key(key, key_prefix, version):
    return key
```

   And i also entered :  'KEY_FUNCTION' : make_key , in redis configuration of caches.

by default in django it returns 
return ':'.join([key_prefix, str(version), key])

To be precise, i was hoping if i pass, "key" then redis data having "key" as key should be fetched, it should not be altered in mid way. Similarly if i write using key as "key", it should not be altered in mid way. Kindly let me know please.

This is really important to me for my project, please let me know is there is any way to do this.

items.title: Redis Cluster support.
items.body:
Redis supports clustered installations since version 3.0 - http://redis.io/topics/cluster-spec.

Adding multiple cluster nodes to `LOCATION` setting seems to work (I think RedisCache only connects to first parsed address, but I'm not sure), but it really doesn't.

For example I have 6 instances (3 masters, 3 slaves), so I add them to my `CACHES/default/LOCATION`: `redis://example.com:7000,redis://example.com:7001,...`
Then I try to read key, that is actually on example.com:7004 and get `ResponseError: MOVED 9445 127.0.0.1:7004`.

Using `ShardClient` or `HerdClient` with list of locations doesn't work either.

Please suport Redis Cluster!

items.title: Does calling get_redis_connection() multiple times open multiple connections?
items.body:
My django application makes multiple calls to `get_redis_connection()` in the course of each web request.  I would say it's around 3-6 calls to `get_redis_connection()` per request.

Should I be concerned about any potential resource issues?  Are the connections to the redis client cached within a single django web request?  Or does every call to `get_redis_connection()` create a new connection to the redis client?

Sorry if this looks like a support question!  I just don't know how to test this on my own, or where else to ask.  I'd love to have a better understanding of what's going on each time I use this to get raw client access.  Thanks a lot!
